issues.title: IMS Bearing Failure
issues.symptoms: Metallic debris in oil, grinding noise from engine, sudden catastrophic engine failure, oil light flickering
issues.description: The Intermediate Shaft (IMS) bearing is the most feared issue on the M96 engine used in the 986 Boxster. The bearing supports the intermediate shaft that drives the camshafts. When it fails, metal debris circulates through the engine, causing catastrophic damage. Early cars (1997-1999) with the dual-row bearing are less prone, while 2000-2005 cars with the single-row bearing are at higher risk.
fixes: Proactive IMS bearing replacement with upgraded bearing
LN Engineering ceramic hybrid bearing (most popular upgrade)
Plain bearing conversion (eliminates bearing entirely)
Regular oil analysis to detect early bearing wear
Use quality oil and change every 5,000 miles

repairCosts.notes: Critical preventive maintenance. Often combined with RMS and clutch.

issues.title: Rear Main Seal (RMS) Leak
issues.symptoms: Oil drips from bell housing area, oil on clutch (manual), burning oil smell, oil consumption
issues.description: The rear main seal on the M96 engine is known to leak, especially on higher mileage cars. Oil leaks onto the clutch causing slipping and requiring clutch replacement along with the seal. The RMS is located between the engine and transmission, so the job requires engine or transmission removal.
fixes: Replace rear main seal (requires engine/trans separation)
Combine with IMS bearing and clutch if applicable
Use updated Porsche seal (improved design)
Inspect flywheel for oil contamination damage

repairCosts.notes: Requires transmission removal. Often done with IMS bearing.

issues.title: Coolant Pipe Failure
issues.symptoms: Sudden coolant loss, overheating, coolant smell, puddle under car, white smoke from engine bay
issues.description: The 986 uses plastic coolant pipes that run under the intake manifold. These pipes become brittle with age and heat, eventually cracking and causing rapid coolant loss. Because the engine is mid-mounted, overheating can occur quickly without warning.
fixes: Replace with updated OEM plastic pipes
Upgrade to aluminum coolant pipe kit (permanent fix)
Replace coolant tank and hoses at the same time
Consider replacing thermostat during service
This is a preventive maintenance item - don't wait for failure

repairCosts.notes: Replace with aluminum upgrade. Plastic pipes crack with age.

issues.title: Convertible Top Issues
issues.symptoms: Top won't open/close, warning light on dash, hydraulic fluid leak, slow operation, top stops mid-cycle
issues.description: The 986 Boxster's convertible top mechanism is hydraulic and electrically controlled. Common failure points include the hydraulic pump, rams (cylinders), and the micro switches that sense top position.
fixes: Check and refill hydraulic fluid (use correct Pentosin CHF 11S)
Replace hydraulic rams if leaking
Replace or repair hydraulic pump
Adjust or replace micro switches
Replace top transmission if cables are worn
Regular lubrication of moving parts prevents issues

repairCosts.notes: Hydraulic system issues. Microswitches and pump common.

issues.title: AOS (Air/Oil Separator) Failure
issues.symptoms: Rough idle, smoke from exhaust on startup, oil consumption, whistling noise, check engine light
issues.description: The Air/Oil Separator (AOS) is part of the crankcase ventilation system. It separates oil vapor from air before routing it back to the intake. When the AOS fails (usually the internal diaphragm), it can cause vacuum leaks, allow oil into the intake, and cause rough running.
fixes: Replace AOS unit (OEM or aftermarket)
Consider upgraded AOS designs that are more durable
Replace vacuum lines while AOS is accessible
Check and clean throttle body during service
Combine with other under-intake repairs to save labor

repairCosts.notes: Air-Oil Separator. Causes smoke and consumption when failed.

issues.title: Bore Scoring / Cylinder Wear
issues.symptoms: Knocking noise from engine (cold or hot), increased oil consumption, smoke on startup, low compression
issues.description: Some M96 engines develop bore scoring - damage to the cylinder walls that allows oil to pass the piston rings. The cause is debated. Bore scoring can range from minor (cosmetic) to severe (engine rebuild required). It's more common on cars that sit for long periods or are driven short distances.
fixes: Borescope inspection to assess cylinder condition
For minor scoring: monitor and use quality oil
For severe scoring: cylinder sleeve repair or engine rebuild
LN Engineering offers cylinder repair services
Prevention: regular driving, proper warm-up, quality oil

repairCosts.notes: Major engine work. Cylinder sleeving or replacement required.

issues.title: Window Regulator Failure
issues.symptoms: Window drops into door, grinding noise, slow window operation, window off track
issues.description: Like many cars of this era, the 986 uses cable-driven window regulators with plastic components that fail. The cables can fray or the plastic guides can break, causing the window to drop or operate erratically.
fixes: Replace window regulator assembly
Lubricate window tracks to reduce regulator strain
Check and adjust window alignment after replacement
Replace both sides if one fails (the other is likely close behind)

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change for the M96 water-cooled flat-six.
tools: Ramps or jack and jack stands
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes - warm oil drains better.
Drive onto ramps or raise and support the car safely.
Locate the oil drain plug on the bottom of the engine.
Position drain pan and remove the 19mm drain plug.
Allow oil to drain completely - at least 10 minutes.
The spin-on oil filter is located under the car near the oil pan.
Using filter wrench, remove the old filter.
IMPORTANT: Cut open the old filter and inspect for metal debris (IMS warning).
Apply fresh oil to the new filter's gasket.
Thread new filter on by hand until seated, then 3/4 turn more.
Replace the copper crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 37 ft-lbs (50 Nm).
Add 8.5-9 quarts of 0W-40 or 5W-40 synthetic oil.
Start engine and check for leaks.
Check level after 2 minutes and top off as needed.
tips: CRITICAL: Cut open and inspect oil filter for metal debris - early IMS warning sign.
Frequent oil changes (every 5,000 miles) help protect the IMS bearing.
Use quality synthetic oil meeting Porsche A40 specification.
Consider periodic oil analysis to monitor engine wear.

diyGuides.title: Convertible Top Maintenance
diyGuides.description: Keep your Boxster top working smoothly with regular lubrication.
steps: Lower the convertible top fully to access all mechanism areas.
Inspect the hydraulic rams for any signs of leaking fluid.
Locate the pivot points on the top mechanism links.
Apply white lithium grease to all pivot points and hinges.
Lubricate the guide rails where the top slides.
Apply silicone spray to the rubber seals (top perimeter).
Inspect the fabric for any tears, wear spots, or loose stitching.
Check the rear window for delamination or cracks.
Operate the top up and down 2-3 times to distribute lubricant.
Wipe away excess lubricant that could attract dirt.
Check hydraulic fluid level in the reservoir if accessible.
Verify both microswitches are working (top should stop at endpoints).
tips: Don't operate the top if it's wet or below freezing.
A slow-operating top often means low hydraulic fluid.
The hydraulic pump is in the rear storage compartment.
Use Pentosin CHF 11S for any hydraulic fluid top-off.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement on the 986's Brembo calipers.
steps: Loosen lug bolts while car is on the ground.
Raise and support the car safely on jack stands.
Remove wheel to access caliper.
Disconnect brake pad wear sensor if equipped.
Remove the two 7mm Allen caliper guide pin bolts.
Swing the caliper up and support it - don't let it hang by the hose.
Remove the old pads from the caliper bracket.
Inspect rotor for scoring, cracks, or minimum thickness.
Clean pad contact surfaces with wire brush and brake cleaner.
Open brake fluid reservoir, then compress caliper piston.
Apply brake grease to pad backing plate contact points.
Install new pads - wear sensor slot goes on the inner pad.
Swing caliper down and reinstall guide pins to 22 ft-lbs (30 Nm).
Reconnect wear sensor.
Reinstall wheel and torque lugs to 96 ft-lbs (130 Nm).
Repeat for all corners.
Pump brake pedal until firm before driving.
tips: The 986 uses Brembo four-piston calipers on S models.
Open reservoir cap before compressing pistons.
Bed new pads with moderate stops - avoid hard braking initially.
Consider upgrading to ceramic pads for less brake dust.

diyGuides.title: Spark Plug Replacement
diyGuides.description: Replace spark plugs on the M96 flat-six engine.
steps: Allow engine to cool completely.
Open the engine lid for access.
The M96 has 6 spark plugs - accessed from the top of the engine.
Remove the coil packs by disconnecting connectors and removing bolts.
Use compressed air to blow debris from the spark plug wells.
Using spark plug socket and extension, remove each plug.
Inspect old plugs for wear, fouling, or damage.
Check plug gap on new plugs - should be 0.7-0.8mm.
Hand-thread new plugs to avoid cross-threading.
Torque plugs to 18-22 ft-lbs (25-30 Nm).
Apply dielectric grease to coil pack boots.
Reinstall coil packs and connect wiring.
Start engine and verify smooth operation.
tips: Use NGK or Bosch platinum/iridium plugs.
The 986 uses coil-on-plug ignition - no plug wires.
Inspect coil boots for cracks while replacing plugs.
Replace coils if you're experiencing misfires.
